comments.commentBody: I disagree. I think Hillary would be a great president, and a lot of the people calling her a liar and without values, etc., are just repeating what they have read in the media. Is she flawed? Yes. Is Bernie, yes, in many ways. He just hasn't been examined with a microscope for years the way she has.

Probably fewer than 1 percent of people living in Manhattan are hedge fund managers. The whole Brooklyn holier-than-thou thing is pretty insufferable. How can the rest of us keep up with all that cool-ness?

If you really feel you must abstain, don't--instead--write in. Many here would say it's the same thing. But this election is closer than the media --"easily won," thanks to Wall Street, on several levels!--would have us think.
Write in Bernie 2016.

Nader didn't have millions of supporters who voted with their dollars. If you want to make sure Trump wins in November, just keep writing off Sanders base and the Independent electorate, the biggest voting group, who weren't allowed to vote in New York and in other states (but were in Michigan).  In primaries where they were allowed to vote, check out the results.

What gets me "steamed" is how bernie supporters are characterized for their vote - you're right Clinton isn't a horrid candidate. I just don't like the idea of political dynasties, and I don't think she's at all progressive. If I didn't feel this was a moment in time in American politics where a big jump in progress could be made, I'd be fine voting for Hilary. (I'm never too enthused by a centrist though)

But after hearing the talking heads, opinion makers and Clinton enthusiasts sneer at the idea of Sanders as a valid candidate - I'm frankly come to be disgusted by the candidate herself.
Yeah, Clinton had 980,070 votes, Sanders had 720,995.  In percentage terms, Clinton had 57.6% to Sanders 42.4%. That's a 15.2% margin.  Not close at all.
I applaud your self-awareness. Very few Sanders supporters seem to realize how repugnant the "finger-wagging" really is, along with all the other abuse they dish out to Clinton supporters.

Those who shout the loudest are often in the minority. That's why many Bernie supporters (of which I am one) seem continuously baffled at Hillary's success. Remember the "silent majority"? It exists in the Democratic Party particularly nowadays. HRC supporters keep it to themselves rather than get finger wagged by Bernie's exuberant acolytes. I support Bernie (age 39), both my parents (73, 66) quietly vote Hillary.

The disaster is the junior senator from Vermont. For 40 years he has denounced the Democratic Party, including wanting President Obama challenged in 2012. And unlike Sec. Clinton, Bernie Sanders has done virtually nothing to help the DNC and state Democratic parties this cycle. Now rather than accepting the inevitability of the math he and his campaign has turned caustic and indeed destructive. The real disaster will be in the Fall if Sanders does not firmly exhort his supporters to vote for Sec. Clinton, thereby keeping the White House in Democratic hands.

PS: Not everyone in Upstate New York voted for Sanders: Onondaga County (Syracuse) and Monroe County (Rochester) went for Sec. Clinton. Oh and Erie County (Buffalo) did too.

Same day registration for the general election would be helpful and democratic. THis is a party primary. It's to permit Democrats to select their leader. Open primaries have been shown to foster "Anti-candidate votes". If people really treasure their status as Independents, fine, Keep that status, but then don't complain when long-standing rules have kept you from voting. It's bad enough that Bernie Sanders has been a Democrat for less than a year. It's unfathomable, that he and his followers are crying foul about a closed party primary. Join the party or stay home.

Well, um, Hillary has been trying to talk about issues from the get-go. And Sanders was on board with that. Until he wasn't winning. After that, it has been all Paid Speeches, The System Is Rigged, PACs, Paid Speeches, PACs, & The System Is Rigged.

So yes, I agree!

As the primary season moves forward and Ms. Clinton looks increasingly likely to be the Democratic nominee, I hope she can now shift the dialogue around the party platform for the issues that are also important to her huge base - women!  The near complete absence of discussion and debate about "women's issues" has been infuriating.  I know that Sanders (and probably many of his supporters" deem these issues as "distractions," but they are critically important to me.  We have a Supreme Court vacancy and a Roe v. Wade decision hanging in the balance.  Why haven't the candidates been discussing this??  Why hasn't Planned Parenthood and other women's health programs been front and center to the discussion?  Why has Sanders agenda supplanted all others?  It's time to start a serious discussion here - the sole issue is not Wall Street.
How did they "repudiate" her. That is exactly the opposite of everything I have read. Sources please.

Yes. Convoluted tax rules do not increase enrollments, but free college education surely would. And since endowments in some instances are huge (evidenced by said donations), free college education is not out of reach. Plus, with "secular stagnation" afflicting the world economies (as per Summer's accounts), one road to greater consumer demand is free college education, which often leads to higher incomes, and therefore more disposable income.

Sorry for the confusion.

I agree with you. I have the same thoughts about Rubio and other other candidates. Before the March 15th vote they should have rallied behind Cruz and say, OK lets support this guy to end the Trump Train. I'll be honest I don't know much about Cruz or what he stands for, but I do know you can't really pick a worse person than Trump. So same rule applies, if you care about your party, if you care about the American people you do your best to stop Trump in his tracks. The Republicans failed miserably. Its not too late for the Democrats. But as it is now Hillary and Bernie are not exactly having a love fest and they disagree sharply on some very important issues.
It would be helpful if Jill Stein had a resume of at least winning a school committee race.  The thought that she could win the presidency is laughable.

If you read this piece carefully you would see that it's the affluent whose votes are helping Hillary. the 350k/couple admission fee to the fundraiser doesn't sound very middle class to me? Maybe it does to you because you make enough to not be bothered by that. But Hillary is the Corporate America's little doll and as horrible sounding as Trump is, he might not be as a big sell out as Hill since he's got enough money of his own and doesn't need to be bought. Hillary might be rich now, but that's only because she sold her soul to enough bidders to this far. I personally would NOT vote for neither candidates if those are Hillary and Donny. Two egotistical maniacs who only care about power and money. But I will probably enjoy seeing Trump beat her, as much as despise Trump too.

Realistically, if Bernie is truly committed to those ideas he's built his campaign on, he needs to consider leaving the race, throwing his support behind Hillary and campaigning for her as actively as she campaigned for Obama in 2008.

A Republican President would absolutely decimate the lower- and middle-classes he claims to love. As much as I disagree with him on some things, I have to believe he knows that.

How would Mr. Gurley have been alive if he were white? If he were in the dark stairwell when the gun was fired, unknown to the officer that he was there, with the same wound as Mr. Gurley, he definitely would have been dead.

I am also not sure that Mr. Liang would have been in prison, were Mr. Gurley white. In fact, I think Mr. Liang would have been given the benefit of the doubt often given to cops were Mr. Gurley white but that, in the current climate, Mr. Liang was more likely to be charged because Mr. Gurley was black. This is not to say whether he should have been charged or not. It is to say that there might have been some mixed motives in charging him--conscious or unconscious and unintentional.

Mr. Thompson was operating in the context of a grand jury that did not indict Mr. Pantaleo for causing a death that he could have prevented. Darren Wildon was not indicted for a death that some believe he unjustifiably caused. Mr. Liang was low-hanging fruit.

I much doubt, or at least hope not, that Mr. Thompson was more likely to charge Liang because he is Asian. But he or a white officer may, but hopefully not, have been more likely to have been charged than a black officer. Mr. Thompson was truly operating in a very difficult context. He might, or might not, be aware of how context influenced his decision-making. He might have made the same decision if the officer's or Mr. Gurley's race were different. But he and we will never know.

@Dan

If Mr. Liang were a newly hired bus driver, distracted by playing with his cell phone, that ran a red light, killing someone, he would be in jail.

If Mr Liang were a doctor, administering a powerful sedative to a patient (e.g. Michael Jackson) and left to "use the bathroom" and his patient died, he would be in jail.

If Mr Liang were a care giver that left "for two minutes" unattended, a toddler in his care and it drowned, he would be in jail.

What Mr. Liang did was reckless. There was nothing in his training or lack thereof, that justified him having his gun out. If he were in pursuit of a suspect, was in a gun fight, or had another valid reason to have his gun out, then it may have been an "accident."

Like bus drivers, doctors, pilots and such, he chose a profession that puts the lives of others in his hands.

Mr Liang, as amember of a long marginalized ethnic group, finally standing up for themselves-albeit, misguided in this case, was a able to garner undue sympathy, with his hapless "aww shucks" son of an immigrant narrative.

If he were any other color, he would be in jail.

It is a terrible tragedy that Peter Liang killed Akai Gurley. Thankfully, the New York State Supreme Court avoided adding yet another tragedy to this sad story. I feel that the justice system worked here (albeit at the eleventh hour). Peter Liang was being used as a scapegoat to atone for the crimes of other officers in other killings.
Excellent point.

i'm not looking it as brutality. Cops need to be held accountable just like the rest of us.  How about this guy in Philly who was arrested today for negligently shooting his 5 year old child?  Think that was fair?  Based on race?? He too had his gun out, finger on the trigger, and accidently shot his kid.  I'm going to follow that story and see how it transpires.  i bet this guy will do time in prison. all the while...

This can all be true, and much is true. Yet, simultaneously, it can be true that Mr. Liang should perhaps have not have been charged or not convicted. One does not exclude the other.  Was he charged and convicted, in part at least, for someone else's sin?

Killing blacks - really did anyone expect a non-black officer to go to jail for killing a black man.

The only cops they put in jail for anything are the black cops who do what the non-black cops do every day.

God bless the Gurley family.  The utter lack of sympathy/empathy expressed here for the decedent and his family is appalling.  Officer Liang lost a job; Akai Gurley is lost forever.  Please stop with the comments attempting to equate the losses.

New Orleans is a beautiful, historical city with the best hospitality I've experienced anywhere. The people are so nice that everyone feels like someone you grew up with. There's no better food in North America.

It's inexcusable that they have such high poverty and crime rates, due to horrible government (especially at the state level), and disinterest from the federal government. They need to figure out a way to use tourist money to break the cycle of crime and poverty.
I know Ryan: The "bullet" shot out of the gun; the "bullet" bounced off the wall and...

Dan- what will happen to the guy in Philly who accidentally shot his small child?  He was arrested today.  Ibet he'll do some time in prison. I'll be following the story and see what happens..  Hope everyone else will too.  BTw- it isn't "Crazed" hatred for cops,  it's when you've been at the "Wrong" and innocent end of the stick or have personally seen many of them in action.  i suppose you've been living in some rich upper Eastside "paradise" and haven't seen or felt them in action. Some cops are good, but even the good ones go along with the rotten apples.
Dear Danny boy- Either you didn't understand my sarcastic humor or you can't even read, or maybe it's a little of both.  I suspect, it's a little of both.  Cheers.   Say, did you hear about the ...?

Well put. I agree. Sanders should do what he and his voters and campaign decide, of course. But Mr. Sanders has lately morphed into a person unrecognizable from the person I first met in this campaign.

His discovery that New York ran a closed primary. which he and his team should have known as professional campaigners, is now to blame the Democrats, causing his young supporters to call the game 'rigged', and alienate them from the party. He further says that 3million independent voters are disenfranchised because of these rules. Bernie Sanders has under his charge millions of young voters - he has, imo, a responsibility to instill in them fair play and to accept rules and regulations, not to incite them otherwise. They are understandably disappointed and furious - that's where their mentor should have stepped in. His campaign team should have looked into various eligibility questions for all the primary/caucus states.

Bernie has indeed raised the consciousness of many - although the inequality bit has been with us for years. Still, that was his campaign and it was effective. But his my way or my way style is dogmatic and wearying. If he still sees a way forward, he should continue. But if he finds a way to remain relevant, help his adopted party and the country move forward, and continue to inspire his followers, even better.

Bernie can stay in, and likely will because he is an egomaniac. Much like his entire Congressional career, he's all talk no action, and you'll have to drag him away from the podium before he gives up the spotlight. He has completely cast aside the civility he promised in a desperate attempt to remain relevant, with no regard for how it would reflect on either him or Hillary in the general election. So, respectfully, I disagree NYT editorial board. Bernie needs to go before he usurps this election for his own needs any further.
